forum.name: What Matters in Teaching Mathematics
forum.intro:
In this activity, you will be viewing three video clips of mathematics teaching that illustrate contrasting instructional approaches. The videos are of different levels (adult education, community college, high school) doing different mathematics. While the videos are not all of adult learners, you will likely recognize some of the teaching approaches. Also, these clips are not meant to be examples of best practices or meant to represent “bad” practices. Indeed, effective instructors may use different and sometimes contrasting practices to serve different purposes, even within a single instructional period. Rather, these clips are offered to stimulate your thinking about what matters in good mathematics teaching for adult learners.

As you watch the videos, take notes on the following:

  1. What do you notice about what the instructor is doing and not doing?
  2. What was the experience like for the students?
  3. Whether and how the teaching revealed insights into how to accomplish the program’s key learning objectives:
    • Build procedural fluency from conceptual understanding using a variety of math tasks.
    • Center students’ mathematical thinking and ideas.
    • Engage students in mathematical discussion.
    • Foster students’ positive beliefs and dispositions about mathematics and mathematics learning.

Video 1: Video clip from a high school trigonometry lesson about using the tangent function to determine the height of objects (from the IRIS Center).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jrMFkpn6NPc

The IRIS Center. (2017). High-quality mathematics instruction: What teachers should know. Retrieved from https://iris.peabody.vanderbilt.edu/module/math/.

Please note that the above link will take you to the source of the video and a separate training module not connected to ANI 2.0. You do not need to complete this training module. 

Video 2: Video clip from an adult education class doing a lesson about functions (from the CCR Standards-in-Action Professional Development Units).

https://youtu.be/_KqqLa32hec

Standards-in-Action Mathematics Advanced Unit 3: Observing College and Career Readiness Standards in Action, produced under U.S. Department of Education Contract ED-VAE-13-C-0066 with StandardsWork Inc., 2016.

Video 3: Excerpts of a classroom video from a community college statistics class working on a task involving measures of central tendency. Given sets of test scores from two different classes, they should determine which class did “better” (from Carnegie Math Pathways at WestEd).

https://youtu.be/6b2dCTQ9Rc4

From Carnegie Math Pathways by WestEd. Adapted with permission from WestEd.

Discussion

Reflecting upon these videos as well as your own experiences as a math learner and teacher, share what you think are five things that are important for good mathematics teaching of adult learners. (“Things” can be anything—practices, values, goals, tools, approaches, etc.)

Click ADD DISCUSSION TOPIC to add a post in the forum below.

  • Be specific and cite examples (or non-examples) from the videos and your experiences.
  • In addition, note whether and how conceptual understanding and procedural knowledge are addressed in the clips.
  • After posting, read through other participants’ submissions and share your comments or questions in response to their postings. (Click “Discuss this topic” on an individual post, then click “Reply” to respond to that post.)
